title: Blue Creek Metropark
text:
Blue Creek Metropark is a park and <a href="Conservation%20Area">conservation area</a> in <a href="Whitehouse%2C%20Ohio">Whitehouse</a> and <a href="Waterville%20Township%2C%20Lucas%20County%2C%20Ohio">Waterville Township, Ohio</a>, owned by <a href="Metroparks%20Toledo">Metroparks Toledo</a> and partially leased to the city of Whitehouse. 
The rustic area has a parking lot and a one-mile loop trail leading to a wetland and a quarry pond. Fishing is permitted in the pond. A temporary restroom is located in the parking lot. 
The park has exposed <a href="Glacial%20striation">glacial striations</a> dating back 12,000 years, formed when glaciers pushed granite over limestone.
History.
In the 18th century, the <a href="Wyandot%20people">Wyandot</a>, <a href="Potawatomi">Potawatomi</a>, <a href="Ottawa%20%28tribe%29">Ottawa</a>, and <a href="Chippewa">Chippewa</a> lived on the land. By the 19th century, it was being used for quarrying <a href="limestone">limestone</a>. This was the case until <a href="Toledo%2C%20Ohio">Toledo</a> purchased the property in 1917 as the location of the Toledo House of Corrections, which was used until 1991.
In 2019 the <a href="Ohio%20Department%20of%20Natural%20Resources">Ohio Department of Natural Resources</a> installed a <a href="seismometer">seismometer</a> at the park to monitor the Bowling Green Fault Line.
